Graphite oxide as catalyst for diastereoselective Mukaiyama aldol reaction of 2-(trimethylsilyloxy)furan in solvent free conditions Maria Rosaria Acocella ⁎ Martina De Pascale Mario Maggio Gaetano Guerra ⁎ Department of Chemistry and Biology, University of Salerno, Via Giovanni Paolo II, 132-84084 Fisciano, SA, Italy Department of Chemistry and Biology, University of Salerno Via Giovanni Paolo II Fisciano SA 132-84084 Italy ⁎ Corresponding authors. Graphical abstract Abstract Graphite oxide efficiently promotes the stereoselective Mukaiyama aldol reaction of 2-(trimethylsilyloxy) furan in solvent free conditions assuring a good level of diastereoselectivity. The catalyst can be easily recovered and reused making the procedure cheap and sustainable. The GO ability to control the stereochemical pathway opens new scenes for the possible application in other synthetic transformations. Keywords Graphite oxide Diastereoselectivity Mukaiyama-aldol reaction Solvent free 1 Introduction Carbocatalysis is a new research field based on the use of carbon materials as catalysts. Even it is already known the ability of graphene, graphite and graphite oxide (GO) to efficiently catalyzed some important organic reactions such as Friedel–Crafts [1,2], oxidations [3], reductions [4], Mukaiyama–Michael reaction [5], this field is still beginning to emerge. The availability, the convenient price and the high sustainability of graphite oxide, make it the right choice to project and build a new way for doing organic chemistry. Graphite oxide has been already used in aza-Michael reactions [6], Friedel–Crafts reaction [7] and ring opening polymerization [8] as solid acid and as oxidant catalyst for alcohol [9–11] and thiol oxidation [12], but in every case high catalyst loading was necessary to obtain the reaction product in good yield. In our previous paper [5] the ability of exfoliated graphene oxide (eGO) to efficiently promote the Mukaiyama –Michael reaction of 2-(trimethylsilyloxy) furan to nitroalkenes was demonstrated with an unprecedent diastereoselective control in favor of anti diastereoisomer with 0.02wt% of catalyst loading. The ability to control the stereochemical pathway has opened new perspectives for the possible application in some other organic transformations. One of the most important is the aldol reaction, recognized as one of the most selective and efficient method for stereoselective CC bond forming reaction. In particular, addition of enolsilyl ether and O-silyl-dienolates to aldehydes, well known as Mukaiyama aldol reaction [13], represents an useful way to easily obtain building blocks for the synthesis of biologically and pharmacologically active compounds [14,15]. In particular, the catalytic coupling of 2-(trimethylsilyloxy)furan with aldehydes in presence of Lewis acids is one of the most efficient method for the synthesis of δ-hydroxy-α,β-unsaturated-γ-lactones, versatile building block for the synthesis of several biologically active natural products [16–18]. Lewis acids such as BF3-OEt2, TMSOTf, ZnCl2, TiCl4, SnCl4, SiCl4 [19–21] or recently bismuth triflate [22] and iodine [23] have been known to catalyze this reaction under strictly anhydrous conditions or to promote the reaction at very low temperature (−78°C). The use of metal incorporated mesoporous/zeolite materials were also reported as active heterogeneous catalysts, but the presence of metals and the use of toxic solvents can limit the application of these procedures [24,25]. Even the attempt to formulate ecofriendly procedure by using organocatalyst [26], or performing the reaction in absence of catalyst as reported by Curti et al. [27], cannot exclude the use of toxic organic solvents dangerous for the human and environmental health. In order to make a new ecofriendly and sustainable procedure to obtain δ-hydroxy-α,β-unsaturated-γ-lactones, the graphite oxide was tested as a possible catalyst for the Mukaiyama aldol reaction. Herein we report a simple, convenient and metal free diastereoselective Mukaiyama aldol reaction of 2-(trimethylsilyloxy) furan to aldehydes in presence of catalytic amount of graphite oxide in solvent free conditions. 2 Materials and methods 2.1 Materials High surface area graphite, with Synthetic Graphite 8427® as trademark, was purchased from Asbury Graphite Mills Inc., with a minimum carbon wt% of 99.8. Aldehydes, 2-(trimethylsiloxy)furan, sulphuric acid, sodium nitrate, potassium permanganate were purchased from Sigma–Aldrich and used without any further purification. TLC was performed on silica gel 60 F254 0.25mm on glass plates Merck and non-flash chromatography was performed on silica gel (0.063–0.200mm) (Merck). 2.2 Preparation of graphite oxide Graphite oxide samples were prepared by Hummers’ method [28], from graphite samples. 120mL of sulphuric acid and 2.5g of sodium nitrate were introduced into a 2000mL three-neck round bottomed flask immersed into an ice bath and 5g of graphite were added, under nitrogen, with a magnetic stirring. After obtaining an uniform dispersion of graphite powders, 15g of potassium permanganate were added very slowly to minimize the risk of explosion. The reaction mixture was thus heated to 35°C and stirred for 24h. The resulting dark green slurry was firstly poured into a copious amount of deionized water, and then centrifuged at 10,000rpm for 15min with a Hermle Z 323K centrifuge. The isolated GO powder was washed twice with 100mL of a 5wt% HCl aqueous solution and subsequently with deionized water. Finally, it was dried at 60°C for 12h. The powder obtained was fully characterized by IR, elemental analysis, BET and TGA and reported as Supplementary content. 2.3 Exfoliation of graphite oxide by ball-milling Graphite oxide powders were introduced in 125mL ceramic jars (inner diameter of 75mm) together with stainless steel balls (10mm in diameter) and were dry-milled in a planetary ball mill (Retsch GmbH 5657Haan) for 2h with a milling speed of 500rpm and a ball-to-powder mass ratio of 10–1. 2.4 General procedure for Mukaiyama aldol addition of 2-(trimethylsilyloxy) furan to 4-tolualdehyde The reaction was carried out in a vial. 4-tolualdehyde (75mg, 0.62mmoL) and 2-(trimethylsiloxy)furan (1.2eq, 0.74mmoL, 123μL) were added to the GO catalyst (1wt%) at room temperature. The reaction was stirred at the same temperature for the time indicated. The progress of the reaction was monitored by TLC. The reaction mixture was extracted with AcOEt, and the combined organic phase was dried (Na2SO4) and concentrated. The diastereoisomeric ratio was determined on the crude reaction via 1H NMR and then the crude was purified by column chromatography on silica gel via gradient elution with Hexane/AcOEt to obtain the pure product. 3 Results and discussion The graphite oxide (GO) and exfoliated graphite oxide (eGO) samples used as catalysts in this paper were prepared by Hummers' oxidation [28] of high surface area graphite. The X-ray diffraction patterns of the starting graphite and of the derived GO and eGO are reported in Fig. 1 A–C, respectively. The X-ray diffraction pattern of the oxidized sample (Fig. 1B), shows the disappearance of 002, 004 and 101 graphite reflections and the appearance of a broad reflection with spacing d =0.84nm, which corresponds to the 001 reflection of GO [29–32]. It is worth adding that the 001 reflection exhibit a half-height width (β 001 =2°) larger than the 100 reflection (β 100 =0.5°). As a consequence, the correlation length parallel to the graphitic layers (D 100 =30nm) is much higher than the correlation length perpendicular (D 001 =4.5nm). For the milled graphite oxide sample (Fig. 1C), this already broad 001 reflection is nearly completely replaced by a very broad intense halo, centered at d =0.37nm, with a correlation length of about 1nm. This indicates the presence of a large fraction of essentially exfoliated GO.[33] The weak reflection with d =0.76nm and D≈2.5nm can be interpreted as 001 reflection of not exfoliated GO, occurring in an amount lower than 10wt%. The X-ray diffraction pattern of the chemical reduced graphite oxide (Fig. 1D) shows a broad reflection centered at d =0.35nm, clearly indicating the formation of highly disordered graphite (with correlation length D≈2nm). In the following, we will use the terms of graphite oxide (GO), exfoliated graphite oxide (eGO) and chemically reduced graphite oxide (rGO) for the samples of Fig. 1B–D respectively. The powders characterized in Fig. 1 were used as catalysts for the reaction of 2-(trimethylsilyloxy)furan 1 to 4-tolualdehyde 2, chosen as representative substrates Scheme 1 . The preliminary study was focused on the screening of different graphitic materials to verify the possibility to perform the carbocatalyzed reaction. In agreement with a previous work [5], by using GO as catalyst, the reaction proceeds with a good efficiency and a moderate diastereoselective control (70/30) in favor of anti diastereoisomer, at room temperature and in solvent free conditions (entry 1 of Table 1 ). The stereochemical outcome was determined by 1H NMR analysis on the crude products according to previous reports [34]. It is worth adding that this diastereoselective control in so mild and convenient conditions is quite surprising based on that reported in literature [22,23,27]. In fact the use of metal catalysts, very low temperature and often toxic solvents, is usually necessary to obtain good results both in efficiency and stereoselectivity, representing a limit for application of already known procedures in a sustainable context. A further attempt to improve the anti selectivity by lowering the reaction temperature failed. (entry 2 of Table 1). As in the previous paper [5], the use of partially exfoliated GO (eGO) with smaller size particles and enhanced carboxylic functionalities availability was tested for the Mukaiyama-aldol reaction, giving in presence of 0.02wt% catalyst loading good efficiency, although with reduced diastereoselectivity (entry 3, Table 1). It worth adding that, a direct purification without aqueous work up step was required to obtain the product and to avoid a competitive retroaldol reaction occurring in presence of water. A more detailed investigation to better understand this aspect is reported as Supplementary content. We have also investigated the possible catalytic activity of partially reduced graphite oxide rGO (C/O ratio ∼5), (entry 4, Table 1) and of high-surface-area-graphite (entry 5, Table 1) that is active diastereoselective catalyst for Mukaiyama–Michael additions [5], mainly due to the π-stacking of the aromatic substrate with graphite. The reduced efficiency observed in the first case and the complete absence of product in the second one, clearly suggests that the catalytic activity of GO sample is essentially associated with its carboxylic and hydroxyl groups and π-stacking interaction is not able to activate the substrate to the nucleophilic addition. Therefore, in spite of the similar stereochemical outcome giving the anti product for both reactions, it seems quite clear that the stereochemical control exerted by GO is a consequence of a different catalyst activation in the Mukaiyama aldol reaction with respect to the Mukaiyama–Michael addition. In fact, while in Mukaiyama-Michael addition the diastereoselective control was guided by a surface interaction between substrate and graphene layer π systems which leads to an unprecedented anti stereoselectivity, in Mukaiyama-aldol reaction the GO catalytic activity is carried out by a simple acidic activation by carboxylic and hydroxyl functionalities able to drive the formation of the anti diastereoisomer usually observed for H-bond activation [35]. To assess the scope of the reaction a variety of aldehydes variously substituted was reacted with TMSOF 1 in the best reaction conditions (entry 1 of Table 1) Scheme 2 . As reported in Table 2 , in presence of electro withdrawing para substituted aldehydes, the reaction proceeds with good yield and diastereoselectivity up to 90% and 80/20 anti/syn ratio respectively, while the same substituents in ortho-position negatively effects the diastereoselective pathway (Table 2 entry 4 and 6, vs 7 and 9) substantially reducing the d.r to 60/40 anti/syn. It is worth adding that in presence of naphtaldehyde, with a more extensive π system, the reaction does not work at all, possibly due to a steric hindrance that deactivates the substrate to the nucleophilic addition. This confirms that for the Mukaiyama aldol reaction the catalytic ability of GO is essentially due to the acidic functionalities on the catalyst surface. Finally, although already known the lower reactivity of aliphatic aldehydes for aldol reaction with trimethylsilyl derivatives, hexanal was tested for the Mukaiyama aldol reaction with 2-(trimethylsilyloxy) furan, showing the inability of the GO to achieve substantial interactions with the substrate and catalyze the addition reaction (Table 2, entry 12). A good result was, instead, obtained using pyruvate as electrophile, by which was possible to get, although with reduced efficiency, a diastereoselectivity up to 85/15 anti/syn (entry 11 of Table 1) higher than those reported in literature for metal-free catalyzed reaction [36]. As heterogeneous catalyst, the reusability of GO was investigated using the addition of 2-(trimethylsilyloxy)furan 1 to 4-tolualdehyde 2a as the model reaction. The solid GO, recovered after extraction from the aqueous solution and dried at 60°C overnight, was used without any further treatment. The reaction conditions, RT and 48h were kept the same for all the cycles. As shown in Fig. 2 , after an initial reduction of efficiency in the first cycle, the yield of the reaction as well as the diastereoselectivity remained almost unchanged after five recycling steps. 4 Conclusions In short, we have shown the catalytic activity of GO for the Mukaiyama aldol reaction of 2-(trimethylsilyloxy) furan to aldehydes and its ability to control the diastereoselective pathway of the reaction. The reaction proceeds with good efficiency and with good level of diastereoselectivity up to 85/15, in favor of the anti diastereoisomer in solvent free conditions. In spite of the similar stereochemical outcome with the previously reported Mukaiyama–Michael addition [5], in this case the GO catalyst exerts a simple acidic activation by carboxylic and hydroxyl functionalities rather than a substrate activation due to π-stacking interactions. The occurrence of definitely different mechanisms for catalysis by graphite oxide in Mukaiyama–Michael and Mukaiyama aldol reactions, mainly involving π-stacking interactions and acidic activation, is confirmed by the catalytic activity for the same reactions of high-surface area graphite being high and negligible, respectively. The heterogeneous and carbon based nature of catalyst makes it easily recyclable with almost unvaried performance after many cycles. The procedure is sustainable, simple (requiring no anhydrous conditions), cheap, solvent- and completely metal free and confirms the ability of GO to efficiently catalyze several organic reactions with a good diastereoselective control, opening interesting perspectives for its applications in other synthetic organic transformations.
